Generally, researchers focus on the regulation of metal sites rather than surrounding nonmetals in photothermal CO2 hydrogenation reaction. Herein, concerning the role of non-metallic N species, a series of Co/NC-T catalysts have been fabricated via high-temperature pyrolysis of Zeolitic Imidazolate Frameworks-67. The CO2 conversion rate shows a consistent tendency with the ratio of graphitized-N species while the product selectivity is closely related to the coordination state of Co-Nx species. Co/NC-800 catalyst achieves high CO2 conversion rate of 758 mmol gcat -1 h-1 with CH4 selectivity of 99.6 %. After adding extra graphitized-N species, the CO2 conversion rate could further enhance to 80.2 % for N-Co/NC-2. The role of N species in photothermal CO2 hydrogenation reaction has been investigated in details, providing new insights for the design of metal organic frameworks derived metal/N-doped carbon catalysts. Graphical abstract The role of N species of metal/N-doped carbon catalysts in photothermal CO2 hydrogenation reaction was investigated in detail. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Photothermal CO2 hydrogenation ZIF-67 N species Co/NC catalyst Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The concentration of carbon dioxide in atmospheric environment continues to rise at a high speed, leading to severe global warming [1,2]. Solar-driven CO2 conversion to value-added fuels and chemicals presents great research significance for achieving carbon emission peak and carbon neutrality [3–5]. Among these solar-driven CO2 catalytic process, photothermal catalysis, combing the advantages of photo- and thermochemical, which may overcome the low activity in sole solar-driven catalytic processes and the harsh reaction conditions in thermal catalysis, offering new avenues for efficient CO2 conversion under relatively mild conditions [6–9]. Specifically, photothermal catalytic CO2 hydrogenation to CH4 via the Sabatier reaction which could convert CO2 and green hydrogen to methane by solar energy, garnering significant interest recently [10,11]. Regarding photothermal catalytic Sabatier reaction, catalysts are typically based on supported metals nanoparticles (such as Fe, Co, Ni, and Ru), which could transduce light into heat and produce hot electrons to dissociate H2 by utilizing the localized surface plasmon resonance (LSPR) effect [12,13]. Co, as an abundant and low-cost non-noble metal, presenting strong hydrogenation ability as well as moderate bonding strength between CO species, has attracted much attention in photothermal CO2 hydrogenation reaction. For example, Ye's group reported the Co@CoN&C catalyst could achieve the maximum yield rate of 132 mmol h-1·g cat-1 with CO selectivity of 91.1 % [14]. Xiong et al. found Co@NC catalyst could achieve a high CO generation rate of 750 mmol gcat -1 h-1 with CO selectivity of 92.6 % under the full spectrum of light illumination [15]. Wang's group reported a potassium modified Co/C lotus-pod structure which could achieve a high photothermal CO2 hydrogenation rate of 758 mmol g-1 h-1 with CO selectivity of 99.8 % [1]. Specially, most of these publications prove that coating carbon layer not only promote the light absorption but also suppress the agglomeration of Co nanoparticles, thereby enhancing the photothermal CO2 hydrogenation performance. Among various carbon layer coating methods, high-temperature pyrolysis of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) precursors could easily encapsulate metal sites into porous carbon architecture. For instance, Gascon's group investigated Ni-MOF-74 derived Ni@C catalyst for photothermal CO2 hydrogenation reaction. The Ni@C catalyst gave a high CH4 production rate of 488 mmol g-1 h-1 under UV–visible-IR irradiation [16]. Jia et al. found the Ru-ZrO2/C catalyst obtaining from UiO-66 precursors exhibited a CH4 yield of 504.1 mmol g-1 h-1 with selectivity of 98.9 % [17]. Xu et al. reported that Co/CeO2 catalysts deriving from Ce-BTC/ZIF-67 precursors could achieve a CH4 yield of 885.27 mmol⋅g-1 ⋅h-1 with selectivity of 97.34 % [18]. In most cases, researchers focus on the regulation of metal sites rather than the surrounding nonmetal species or their synergistic effect in photothermal CO2 hydrogenation reaction. Doping nitrogen into carbon layer could change the polarity and the electron distribution as well as strengthen the adsorption capability of acidic CO2 molecules [19]. For instance, Zeng et al. found Co4N could interact with H to form Co4NH intermediates, which could provide distinct hydrogen adsorption sites and enrich the hydrogenation paths during CO2 hydrogenation reaction [20]. Zhuo et al. found N species could provide active sites in electrochemical CO2 reduction reaction [21]. To the best of our knowledge, the role of N species for photothermal CO2 hydrogenation reaction remains unclear. In this work, a series of ZIF-67 derived Co/NC catalysts have been prepared and the role of N species in photothermal CO2 hydrogenation reaction have been systematically investigated. It was found that CO2 conversion rate presented a consistent tendency with the ratio of graphitized-N species while the product selectivity was closely related to the coordination state of Co-Nx species. From the results of in situ DRIFT spectra and H2 pretreatment experiments, the Co/NHxC intermediates have been formed via strong interaction between N species and absorbed H atoms. This work provides helpful insights for the design of metal organic frameworks derived metal/N-doped carbon catalysts in CO2 hydrogenation reaction. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Chemicals and materials The starting materials of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (99.99 %), 2-Methylimidazole (2-MeIm, 98 %), methanol (MeOH, 99.9 %), and dicyandiamide (DCDA,99 %) came from Aladdin while NaH13CO3 was brought from Sigma-Aldrich. The gas mixture of CO2: H2: Ar (15 vt% : 60 vt%: 25 vt%) was purchased from Sichuan Tianyi Technology Co., Ltd). 2.2 Synthesis of Co/NC-T catalysts Typically, for the synthesis of ZIF-67, Co(NO3)2·6H2O (20 mmol) and 2-Methylimidazole (80 mmol) were dissolved into 150 mL methanol separately. After mixing of the two solution, the suspension was stirred at room temperature for 24 h The precipitate was collected by centrifugation and washed with MeOH for four times. The as-synthesized ZIF-67 nanoparticles were placed in a tube furnace and heated to 600 ℃, 700 ℃ and 800 ℃ with a heating rate of 3 ℃/min under flowing Ar atmosphere to yield Co/NC-T catalysts, naming as Co/NC-600, Co/NC-700, and Co/NC-800. 2.3 Synthesis of N-Co/NC-m catalysts 200 mg of the as-prepared ZIF-67 and a certain amount of Dicyandiamide (DCDA, 1 mmol, 2 mmol, 5 mmol, and 10 mmol) were dispersed in 50 mL MeOH with ultrasonic for 30 min. Then rotary evaporation was carried out until the MeOH solvent evaporated completely. The mixture was placed in tube furnace and heated to 800 ℃ with a ramp of 3 ℃, donated as N-Co/NC-1, N-Co/NC-2, N-Co/NC-5, N-Co/NC-10. 2.4 Characterization The crystallinity of the as-obtained products was investigated by X-ray diffraction (XRD) (Bruker D8 Advance; Cu Kα = 1.5404 Å, scan rate of 5 o/min). The morphologies and sizes of the samples were characterized by SU8010 field-emission scanning electron microscope (FESEM, Hitachi, Japan) at a decelerating voltage of 2 kV and accelerating voltage of 10 kV. High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) was measured on an FEI F200X microscope which operated on an accelerating mode of 200 kV. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) (VG Multi lab 2000) was carried out to analyze the chemical states of the samples. The UV–Vis diffused reflectance spectra (DRS) were recorded using a Cary Series UV–Vis-NIR Spectrophotometer (Agilent Technologies) from 200 nm to 2000 nm by a diffuse reflectance method using polytetrafluoroethylene as reference material. In-situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) for photothermal CO2 reduction measurement was carried out on a TENSO II FTIR spectrometer (Bruker, Germany) equipped with an in-situ diffuse-reflectance cell (Harrick, USA). 13CO2 isotope labeling experiments were conducted under the following conditions: 170 mg NaH13CO3 were mixed with 100 mg catalysts, and the mixture was placed on a glass reactor, 0.2 MPa of the 10 % H2/Ar gas mixture was injected into the reaction system. 300 W Xe lamp (PLE-SXE300, Perfectlight, China) was used as the light source to drive photothermal CO2 reduction, and the gas products were quantified by gas chromatography (GC-2014, Shimazu)-mass spectrometry (MS, HPR-20, Hiden Analytic). All the 13CO2 was supplied by the NaH13CO3. 2.5 Photo-thermal CO2 hydrogenation experiments Photo-thermal CO2 hydrogenation experiments were carried out in a Teflon-lined stainless reaction chamber (50 cm3) with a quartz window at the top for light irradiation (Fig. S1). The area of quartz glass is 32.15 cm2, and actual light radiation area is 19.62 cm2. For each catalytic test, 100 mg catalysts were uniformly dispersed on a piece of light-permeable quartz fiber filter. By using a mechanical pump, the reaction chamber was completely evacuated to −0.1 MPa. Then reaction gas mixture (vt.%, CO2/H2/Ar = 15/60/25) was injected into the reactor to a pressure of 0.2 MPa. And the evacuation and gas injection procedure were repeated 10 times to flush the reactor. After the injection, the reaction chamber was placed in the dark room for 30 min, which enables mixture gas and catalysts to interact sufficiently and achieve adsorption-desorption equilibrium. A 300 W Xe lamp (Beijing Perfect-light Co. Ltd, PLS-SXE-300UV, light intensity 5.2 W cm-2, coverage from 300 to 2500 nm) was used as light source to drive the CO2 reduction. During the reaction, 0.2 mL of the gas was taken from the reactor by syringe and injected into a gas chromatograph (GC9790II, Fuli instrument) equipped with flame ionization detector (FID) and thermal conductivity detector (TCD). And the experimental procedure of photocatalytic CO2 hydrogenation is the same as the above, but the circuit cooling equipment was maintained in the whole process, besides, photocatalytic CO2 hydrogenation experiment takes 3 h After 2 h photothermal reaction, the catalysts were dried in vacuum at 80 ℃ and carried out the next reaction, the subsequent 15 recycling tests were conducted. The temperature of the catalyst bed was measure by the K type thermocouple (WRNK-191). To detect the difference between photothermal and traditional thermal catalysis, the bottom of the closed-circulation system was wrapped with a flexible electric heating jacket to test the thermal catalytic activity The conversion was calculated by using Equation as following: (1) C o n v e r s i o n = ∑ n p r o / n C O 2 × 100 % (2) S e l e c t i v i t y = S C O = n C O ∑ n p r o × 100 % (3) S C H 4 = n C H 4 ∑ n p r o × 100 % (4) S C 2 H 6 = n C 2 H 6 ∑ n p r o × 100 % (5) S C O = n C O ∑ n p r o × 100 % (6) ∑ n p r o = n C O + n C H 4 + n C 2 H 6 2.6 H2 pretreatment Before the CO2 hydrogenation, the Co/NC series was placed in tube furnace and heated to 300 ℃ with a ramp rate of 5 °C/min for 2 h at 10 % H2/Ar gas flow, after cooling down to room temperature, the catalysts were carried out to photothermal catalytic CO2 hydrogenation and compared to the activity and selectively of samples without H2 pretreatment, which is marked as Co/NHxC. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Photothermal CO2 hydrogenation performance As displayed in Scheme 1 , the Co/NC-T catalysts were synthesized by pyrolysis of ZIF-67 at different temperatures and the N-Co/NC-m catalysts were obtained by pyrolysis of the mixture of dicyandiamide (DCDA) and ZIF-67. The photo-thermal CO2 hydrogenation performance of Co/NC-T and N-Co/NC-m catalysts are displayed in Fig. 1 and Table 1 . All Co/NC-T catalysts show wide-band light absorption in the ultraviolet-visible-near infrared full absorption spectrum. The N-Co/NC-2 exhibits slightly stronger absorption ability than Co/NC-800, suggesting extra introduction of N species into Co/NC-800 could further enhance the light absorption properties (Fig. 1a). The temperatures over different catalysts under a 300 W Xe lamp within full absorption spectrum were monitored, consisting well with the results of absorption spectrum (Fig. 1b). The photo-induced thermochemical reaction temperature of Co/NC-600, Co/NC-700 and Co/NC-800 are 250 °C, 280 °C, and 300 °C, respectively. N-Co/NC-2 keeps the highest reaction temperature (330 °C) during the whole photo-thermal CO2 hydrogenation reaction. As exhibited in Fig. 1c and Table 1, for Co/NC-T catalysts, Co/NC-800 exhibits the highest CO2 conversion rate of 75.3 % with CH4 selectivity of 99.5 % and C2H6 selectivity of 0.5 %. By contrast, the CO2 conversion rate is only 46.7 % for Co/NC-600 and 67.5 % for Co/NC-700, while the CH4 selectivity is 98.0 % and 99.1 %, respectively. NCo/NC-2 presents a CO2 conversion of 80.2 % with a CH4 selectivity of 96.9 % and a C2H6 selectivity of 3 %, wherein, the selectivity of C2H6 product is increased by 5 times as compared to Co/NC-800. Nevertheless, the CO2 conversion rate would decrease to 59.3 % for N-Co/NC-5 and 50.8% for N-Co/NC-10 after further increasing the extra N content (Table 1). To probe photothermal synergistic effect, the thermal CO2 hydrogenation under identical reaction temperature without light irradiation, and photo CO2 hydrogenation under same light irradiation at room temperature have been studied (Fig. 1d). For N-Co/NC-2 catalyst, the CO2 conversion rate of both photocatalytic (26.7 %) and thermo-catalytic (71.6 %) was lower than that of photothermal catalysis (80.2 %). Notably, C2H6 was not detected in the products of either thermo-catalytic or photo-catalytic CO2 hydrogenation reactions. The production of C2H6 was related to the synergistic effect of heat and light (Figs. S2 and S3). Under the irradiation of different wavelengths (UV–vis-NIR, ≥ 365 nm, ≥ 380 nm, and ≥ 420 nm), the CO2 conversion rate is 80.2 %, 78.6 %, 73.6 %, and 60.2 %, respectively, indicating NCo/NC-2 possesses acceptable reaction activity under the irradiation of ultraviolet light (Fig. 1e). Fig. S4 shows the product selectivity under different wavelengths of Xe lamp. The product selectivity does not show obvious change under different irradiation wavelengths. As illustrated in Fig. S5, the activity dramatically enhances with increasing light intensity, demonstrating a positive linear relationship between the CO2 conversion rate and the light intensity. Light irradiation not only increases the surface temperature of catalysts but also induces the energetic hot carriers-mediated activation of reactants to enhance the catalytic activity. The pressure does not influence the CO2 conversion rate and selectivity obviously (Fig. S6). No obvious deactivation could be detected after 15 cycles, demonstrating the high structural stability of N-Co/NC-2 catalysts (Fig. 1f). 3.2 Structural characterization The surface N species of Co/NC-T and N-Co/NC-2 catalysts were investigated by high-resolution XPS technique (Fig. 2 ). Fig. 2a displays the 2p spectrum of Co element, where the two peaks at binding energies of 778.6 eV and 793.5 eV correspond to the 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 orbitals of metallic Co, respectively [22]. The two peaks at 780.1 eV and 795.2 eV could be attributed to the 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 orbitals of Co-Nx species [23]. The intensity ratio could reflect the coordination state of Co-Nx species. There are four N species in Co/NC-T and N-Co/NC-2 catalysts, including Graphite-N, Pyrrole-N, Pyridine-N, and Co-Nx species (Fig. 2c). Among them, Co-Nx and graphitic-N species exhibit strong basicity, enabling adsorption of H atoms [24]. The pyridinic-N possesses lone pair of electrons which is not involved in the π-conjugation of the ring. Thereby, it demonstrates certain ability to adsorb H atoms but weaker than that of graphitic-N [25]. In contrast, the pyrrolic-N in the π-conjugation system of the ring, presenting the weakest ability for H adsorption [26]. For Co/NC-T catalyst, the percentage of graphitic-N and Pyridinic-N increase while the percentage of Pyrrole-N decreases when the thermolysis temperature changes from 600 oC to 800 oC (Fig. 2b and Fig. 2d). For the N-Co/NC-2 catalyst, as compared to Co/NC-800, the percentage of graphitic-N could be further increased from 32.5 % to 38.1 % while the percentage of Pyridinic-N is decreased from 24.0 % to 18.0 % (Fig. 2d, Table S1). The correlation between surface nitrogen species and photo-thermal CO2 hydrogenation performance could be manifested in two aspects. Firstly, due to the presence of alone pair of electrons, N element can adsorb hydrogen as a Lewis base, meanwhile, Graphite-N, Pyridine-N, and Co-Nx all have a strong adsorption effect on H while Pyrrole-N has weaker adsorption of hydrogen, resulting in higher CO2 conversion rate and selectivity of C2 hydrocarbons in the products. The relative ratio of graphitized-N shows a consistent tendency with the CO2 conversion rate owing to graphitic-N species exhibit strong basicity. Secondly, lower pyrolysis temperature means less decomposition of the imidazole structure and larger coordination numbers of Co-Nx, thus leading to weaker adsorption of intermediate CO and higher product selectivity of CO. By contrast, higher pyrolysis temperature results in deeper decomposition of the imidazole ring and smaller Co-Nx coordination numbers, inducing further conversion of CO to hydrocarbon products (CH4 and C2H6) [19]. Therefore, extra introduction of graphitic-N species into Co/NC structure could not only accelerate hydrogenation reaction but also yield C2 product. The pyrolysis temperature not only affect the chemical state of N species but also influence other structural parameters, such as particle size of Co nanoparticles, specific surface area, and pore-size distribution. The physicochemical properties of these catalyst were further investigated by XRD, SEM, HRTEM, Raman, and N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm. TG/DTG spectrum show three distinct regions over the temperature range of 50–550 ℃, 550–650 ℃, and 650–800 ℃ (Fig. 3 a). The evaporation of adsorbed H2O and MeOH occurs in the first stage while the breakage of C-H bonds, N-H bonds and C-N bonds occurs at 550–650 ℃. During this stage, the H/N atoms are detached from the imidazole structure, at the same time, some Co atoms are changed from tetrahedral coordination environment to planar like coordination state (Co-Nx) and the other Co atoms are aggregated into nanoparticles(Figs. S7, S8) [27]. Fig. 3b displays the XRD profiles of the as-obtained Co/NC-T catalysts. The peak at 44.6° indicates the formation of metal Co particles (PDF #88–2325) [28]. The half-peak width of the diffraction peak at 44.6° gradually decreases with higher pyrolysis temperature, indicating the aggregation of Co nanoparticles. Meanwhile, Co/NC-T exhibit similar typical Type-IV isotherm (Fig. 3c). Co/NC-600 shows H3 hysteresis loop while Co/NC-700, Co/NC-800 and N-Co/NC-2 demonstrate H4 hysteresis loop [29]. The specific surface areas (SBET) of Co/NC-600, Co/NC-700, Co/NC-800, and N-Co/NC-2 are 179.9, 239.1, 294.5, and 329.1 m2/g, respectively (Table S2, Fig. S9). The Raman spectra of these Co/NC-T catalysts are presented in Fig. 3d. The peak at approximately 1581 cm-1 represents the in-plane vibration peak of sp2-hybridized carbon atoms (G peak) while the peak at 1340 cm-1 signifies the breathing vibration of sp2-hybridized carbon atom rings (D peak). The ID/IG ratio gradually decreases as the pyrolysis temperature from 600 to 800 ℃, indicating higher degree of graphitization [30]. Fig. S10 shows the FT-IR spectrum for ZIF-67, Co/NC-800 and N-Co/NC-2. For ZIF-67, the absorption bands related to the C-H stretching vibration appear at 3130 cm-1 while the peaks ranging from 1550 cm-1–600 cm-1 (stretching of imidazole ring) disappear in Co/NC and N-Co/NC-2 samples. The peaks ranging from 1300 cm-1–1000 cm-1 correspond to the stretching vibration of C-N [31]. Notably, the peak intensity at 1139 cm-1 (the stretching vibration of the CN bond) in NCo/NC-2 significantly increases as compared to Co/NC-800. SEM images suggest these Co/NC-T samples maintain the regular dodecahedral structure of ZIF-67 while the surface is decorated with Co nanoparticles (Fig. 4 a–d). The lattice fringes with spacing of 0.205 nm could be attributed to the (111) plane of metallic Co phase, respectively [32]. The high-angle annular dark-field (HAADF) and EDX elemental mapping images confirm the uniform distribution of Co, C and N elements in the Co/NC-800 catalysts. The corresponding average size of Co nanoparticles in Co/NC-600, Co/NC-700, Co/NC-800 and NCo/NC-2 are 9.5, 12.2 19.9 and 20.6 nm, respectively (Fig. S11). 3.3 Investigation of reaction mechanisms Fig. 5 a illustrates the CO2-TPD profiles for Co/NC-800 and NCo/NC-2. The desorption peaks located at 543 °C for NCo/NC-2 and 501 °C for Co/NC-800 could be ascribed to CO2 desorption from metal Co particles [15]. Additionally, the amount of CO2 on NCo/NC-2 is obviously larger than that of Co/NC-800 (0.445 vs 0.152 mmol·g −1), suggesting that extra N species could improve the CO2 adsorption ability of Co sites. To confirm whether the generation of hydrocarbons originated from the reduction of CO2, isotope labelling experiments by using 12CO2 or 13CO2 were performed (Fig. 5b). The peak at m/z = 16 or m/z = 17 corresponds to the peaks of 12CO2 or 13CO2 as the sources, respectively, which validate the produced CH4 was indeed from the conversion of CO2. As illustrated in Fig. 5c, H2 pretreatment experiments were carried out to confirm the stronger interaction between N species and adsorbed H atoms. The photothermal CO2 hydrogenation reaction was measured in batch reactor as the control group, simultaneously, the other group was fully interacted in 10 % H2/Ar atmosphere to reach the adsorption and desorption equilibrium, followed by testing the photothermal CO2 hydrogenation reaction activity. For both Co/NC-800 and NCo/NC-2, the group after H2 pretreatment had faster reaction rate for CO2 conversion. The Co/NC-800 catalyst took about 1 h to reach the reaction limit, and NCo/NC-2 approached the equilibrium of the reaction within 20 min, indicating that H2 can indeed adsorb on the surface of the NCo/NC-2 catalysts, which finally results in a faster reaction rate. When compared NCo/NC-2 with Co/Al2O3 catalysts, NCo/NC-2 approached the equilibrium of the reaction within 20 min after H2 treatment while Co/Al2O3 took about 120 min to reach the reaction limit (Fig. 5d). H2 pretreatment experiments confirm the stronger interaction between N species and absorbed H [16]. In situ DRIFTS measurements under 365 nm UV irradiation were implemented to reveal more details of the CO2 hydrogenation process (Fig. 6 ). The peaks at 3390 cm-1 could be assigned to the stretching vibrations of NH, demonstrating that H adsorbed on N rapidly and participated in the CO2 hydrogenation process [33]. The peak at 1560 cm-1 is assigned to the peak of *COOH, indicating that CO2 and H2 have already interacted in dark, enabling the hydrogenation reaction proceeds rapidly after the light exposure. After irradiation for 5 min, the peaks at 2825 cm-1 and 2740 cm-1 correspond to the CH stretching and bending vibration peaks in *CHO, while the peak at 2120 cm-1 is ascribed to the stretching vibration peak of *CO. As the irradiation time increases, these peaks (*CHO and *CO) disappear rapidly. Meanwhile, new peaks at 2830 cm-1 (CH stretching vibration of *CH3 or CH4), and 3100 cm-1 (CH stretching vibration peak of unsaturated olefins) could be observed [34–36]. Thus, the optimal pathway of hydrogenation reaction on NCo/NC-2 catalysts is illustrated in Fig. 7 , as following: *CO2 → *COOH → *CO → *CHO → *CH3 → CH4. After irradiation for 45 min, the intensity of the CH stretching vibration peak of the unsaturated olefin is higher, indicating the presence of *CH2=CH2 species during the reaction. C2H6 have been detected in the product, indicating that the formation of C2H6 may go through in the following two ways: (1) the *CH2 adsorbed on the catalyst surface couples to form the *CH2=CH2 structure. Because of the strong interaction between*CH2=CH2 and Co, *CH2=CH2 could not desorb while the H adsorbed on N can quickly add to *CH2=CH2 to form C2H6. (2) The *CH3 adsorbed on the catalyst surface directly couples to form C2H6 [37,38]. 4 Conclusions In summary, a series of ZIF-67 derived Co/NC-T catalysts have been synthesized to investigate the role of non-metallic N species in photo-thermal catalytic CO2 hydrogenation reaction. It was found that CO2 conversion rate presented a consistent tendency with the ratio of graphitized-N species while the product selectivity was closely related to the coordination state of Co-Nx species. In situ DRIFT spectra and H2 pretreatment experiments proved the strong interaction between N species and absorbed H atoms. This work provides new insights for the design of N-decorated carbon layer coated metal catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Generally, researchers focus on the regulation of metal sites rather than surrounding nonmetals in photothermal CO2 hydrogenation reaction. Herein, concerning the role of non-metallic N species, a series of Co/NC-T catalysts have been fabricated via high-temperature pyrolysis of Zeolitic Imidazolate Frameworks-67. The CO2 conversion rate shows a consistent tendency with the ratio of graphitized-N species while the product selectivity is closely related to the coordination state of Co-Nx species. Co/NC-800 catalyst achieves high CO2 conversion rate of 758 mmol gcat -1 h-1 with CH4 selectivity of 99.6 %. After adding extra graphitized-N species, the CO2 conversion rate could further enhance to 80.2 % for N-Co/NC-2. The role of N species in photothermal CO2 hydrogenation reaction has been investigated in details, providing new insights for the design of metal organic frameworks derived metal/N-doped carbon catalysts.
